title: Encoding of properties file which has the item sets?
body:
I'm planning on creating an open source item set builder, but looking in the .properties file of my account "it's a mess of binary and ascii data." (http://gaming.stackexchange.com/questions/117556/which-folder-file-are-item-sets-saved-in last comment on accepted answer)

I would like to be able to read out the file, get the item set data and then be able to save it again.

Could someone tell me what encoding the properties file has? I know the item sets itself are saved in JSON which can be read using UTF-8, but the rest seems very messy.

replies.body:
I tried manually editing the item sets once.

Least to say it's very complicated, and not likely to work with any "open-source" software library. Remember, League uses Adobe infastructure for most of its coding.

Maybe when they change how the item set creator works in the client (they are planning on doing that soon, to coincide with the client UI updates) it will use a more understandable language.

It's a mess in the file, likely due to the marvelous Adobe structure as you said. The Item Sets are in JSON, which is easily extractable and then convertable into an array, but due to all the garbled text around it, it'll never be properly searchable (unless I start doing some magic with it).

I was then planning to use the Riot API to create a JSON file which would ship with the application (and would be updated when needed).

You say they're planning on changing how it works soon, do you have a source of that? Boards or Reddit or something?

If you do some "magic" with it, I'd like to know *how* you did it, purely out of curiosity.

And yes, they announced that they would be changing the way the patcher and "landing" page looks. [Here's the official announcement on the NA site.](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/features/patcher-landing-page-visual-refresh-pbe) There's a lot of yibber yabber about it if you are curious, but I'll just block quote the most relevant parts here.

> Let's start with a quick definition: when we talk about "the client," we're speaking to the technology ecosystem that supports your pre-game experience. Each interaction you have while getting ready for a match is built on a base of interconnected systems, all of which work in concert to get you into your games.

>As a result, maintaining League's stability outweighs almost every other priority we have when making changes. Before we can tackle big feature changes, we need to make sure any core technology that we're introducing is robust enough to get the job done. With that in mind, we chose our first targets by looking for the least risky pieces of the client to update. The look and feel of the patcher and the client landing page emerged as choices that let us introduce new tech, minimize risk and deliver some neat stuff.

>Our first few releases will be starting points that'll provide insight into how we should update additional systems. We'll be refining and improving the pre-game experience as we go, which allows us to safely improve the client over time. 

And that is eventually followed by:

>Overall, your pre-game experience won’t change too much with this first release. The actual patching process is still the same, so don't expect performance gains or increased download speeds. Additionally, you’ll still be using the same mastery interface, store, chat system, etc. While our end-goal is to deliver you an improved pre-game experience, our biggest priority is making sure we continue to provide a reliable and stable client and game.

While they haven't explicitly announced that they'll be changing how the masteries, runes and item sets (basically, everything considered to be "parchment" in the coding (the parts of the client that are made to look as though they're on an ancient piece of paper, such as runes, masteries, leagues and item sets)), they have **heavily implied** that they want to update it Soon(tm).

>While this technology won’t noticeably change your pre-game experience, it will help us plan our future updates.

The announcement was written by ventropy around August last year.
Sounds very promising. Certain looking forward to that. Maybe 3rd-party applications will be easier to make soon with those changes. I think it will be easier when they're making it server side.

The keyword in my previous message is "Soon(tm)". It may be a *long* time before they update the item sets.

Just letting you know, mainly, so that you know there's a slim chance that all of your work here will be for nothing around the time you complete it.

The more you know.

Best of luck!
It's just an idea, a plan more or less. Busy with work is keeping me from making this a reality (on top of the garbled mess of a file)
